text:
*[Bug 17604] approx's new na.rm=FALSE does not play well with 'ties' argument.  (R-devel post 3.6.1)*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17604>

Jesse Alderliesten (<mailto:jessealderliesten@hotmail.com|jessealderliesten@hotmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |jessealderliesten@hotmail.c
                   |                            |om

--- Comment #4 from Jesse Alderliesten (<mailto:jessealderliesten@hotmail.com|jessealderliesten@hotmail.com>) ---
(In reply to Siddhesh Akole from comment #3)
Hi Siddhesh, to locate the function regularize.values, you can search for it on
the r-devel GitHub page <https://github.com/r-devel/r-svn>. This finds the
function definition in the file src/library/stats/R/approx.R. It also finds
some other places where the function is used, and the mentioning of it in the
NEWS.3 file, located in doc/NEWS.3.

In R itself, you can use getAnywhere(regularize.values) to find where functions
or objects are located. The first line of the output then reports which
namespace it is in, in this case the 'stats' package.

Using ?regularize.values in R does not work because regularize.values is an
internal (i.e., non-exported) function such that there is no help-page
associated with it. Therefore you need to use stats:::regularize.values to get
the source code from within R.

(In reply to Siddhesh Akole from comment #3)
Hi Siddhesh, to locate the function regularize.values, you can search for it on
the r-devel GitHub page

. This finds the
function definition in the file src/library/stats/R/approx.R. It also finds
some other places where the function is used, and the mentioning of it in the
NEWS.3 file, located in doc/NEWS.3.

In R itself, you can use getAnywhere(regularize.values) to find where functions
or objects are located. The first line of the output then reports which
namespace it is in, in this case the 'stats' package.

Using ?regularize.values in R does not work because regularize.values is an
internal (i.e., non-exported) function such that there is no help-page
associated with it. Therefore you need to use stats:::regularize.values to get
the source code from within R.
